stem: The pediatric nurse is reviewing the developmental records for two infants. Based on the documentation in the Infant Growth & Developmental Milestones tab, match each finding to the correct age group.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 6-month-old male brought in for vaccinations. He is sitting with support and recently started rolling in both directions. 
Patient 2: 12-month-old female. Parents state she is crawling rapidly and 'walking' while holding onto the coffee table (cruising). She can pick up small cereal pieces with her thumb and forefinger.

tabs.title: Developmental Milestones
tabs.content:
MilestonePatient 1 (6 mo)Patient 2 (12 mo)
Gross MotorRolls over both waysCruising / First steps
Fine MotorPalmar grasp (whole hand)Neat pincer grasp
LanguageBabbling 'ba-ba'3-5 words (Mama/Dada)
ReflexesMoro reflex goneBabinski may still be +

tabs.title: Growth Stats
tabs.content:
Patient 1: Birth weight doubled. 
Patient 2: Birth weight tripled.

rows.text: Sitting without support and doubling birth weight
Walking with help (cruising) and tripling birth weight
Using a neat pincer grasp (thumb and forefinger)
Saying 3â€“5 words and following simple one-step commands

rationale.correct: At **6 months**, birth weight has doubled, sitting is becoming independent, and babbling begins (r1, r4). By **12 months**, weight has tripled, cruising/walking occurs, and fine motor skills like the neat pincer grasp are developed alongside a small vocabulary (r2, r3, r5).
clinicalPearls: Birth weight: Doubles at 6 mo, Triples at 12 mo, Quadruples at 24 mo.
Pincer grasp (10-12 mo) is crucial for feeding independence.
The Moro (startle) and Palmar grasp reflexes should be gone by 6 months.

questionTrap.trap: Believing a 6-month-old should have a pincer grasp.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that fine motor control starts at the palm (6 mo) and moves to the fingertips (12 mo).
